q: What command creates a new branch in Git?
How do you switch to an existing branch?
What command creates and switches to a new branch in one step?
How do you delete a local branch?
What is the purpose of branches in Git?
o: To develop features in isolation without affecting main code

q: What does `git branch` without arguments show?
How do you list all branches including remote branches?
What symbol indicates the current branch in `git branch` output?
What happens if you try to delete a branch you are currently on?
o: Git shows an error and prevents deletion
It deletes and switches to main

q: What does `git branch -D` do?
o: Force deletes a branch even if not merged

q: What is a merge conflict?
o: When Git cannot automatically merge changes from different branches

q: What command renames the current branch?
How do you rename a branch you are not currently on?
What does `git switch` do?
How does `git switch` differ from `git checkout`?
o: switch is only for branches, checkout handles files too

q: What does `git switch -` do?
o: Switches to the previously checked out branch

q: How do you create a branch from a specific commit?
What is the default branch usually called in Git repositories?
What does `git branch -r` show?
How do you see the last commit on each branch?
What happens to uncommitted changes when switching branches?
o: They carry over if no conflict, otherwise Git blocks switch

q: How do you force switch branches with uncommitted changes?
o: Stash or commit first; no direct force switch

q: What does `git checkout -f` do when switching?
What does a tracking branch do?
o: Links local branch to a remote branch

q: How do you set up tracking for an existing local branch?
What does `git switch --track origin/feature` do?
o: Creates local feature branch tracking remote

q: How do you see which remote branch a local branch is tracking?
What is a topic branch?
o: Short-lived branch for a specific feature or fix

q: What is a feature branch?
o: Branch dedicated to developing a single feature

q: What command shows branches merged into current branch?
What does `git branch --no-merged` show?
o: Branches not yet merged into current branch

q: What happens when you delete a merged branch?
o: Only the branch pointer is deleted, commits remain

q: What happens if you delete an unmerged branch with -d?
How do you create a branch that points to HEAD~3?
What is the difference between local and remote branches?
o: Local are on your machine, remote tracking branches reference server

q: How do you delete a remote branch?
What does `git push origin :branch-name` do?
How do you fetch all remote branches?
What is origin in Git?
o: Default name for the remote repository

q: How do you see details about a specific remote?
What does `git branch --copy` do?
o: Creates a copy of a branch

q: What is the syntax for `git branch -c`?
What command lists branches that contain a specific commit?
What does `git branch --no-contains <commit>` show?
o: Branches that do not contain the commit

q: How do you list only branches that point to a specific commit?
What is detached HEAD state?
o: When HEAD points directly to a commit instead of a branch

q: How can you end up in detached HEAD state?
o: Checking out a commit, tag, or remote branch directly

q: What warning does Git give in detached HEAD state?
o: Changes may be lost if you switch without creating a branch

q: How do you save work done in detached HEAD state?
What does `git checkout <tag>` do?
o: Checks out the tagged commit in detached HEAD state

q: What is a hotfix branch?
What is a release branch?
o: Branch for preparing a new production release

q: What is the develop branch in GitFlow?
o: Integration branch for features before release

q: What command shows branch creation time?
o: Git does not track branch creation time; use reflog

q: How do you check when a branch was last updated?
o: git log -1 <branch> to see last commit date

q: What does `git for-each-ref --sort=-committerdate refs/heads/` do?
o: Lists branches sorted by most recent commit

q: How do you configure default branch for new repositories?
What is `git show-branch` used for?
o: Shows branches and their commits in a visual format

q: What happens to remote tracking branches when the remote branch is deleted?
o: They remain until pruned with git fetch --prune

q: What does `git remote prune origin` do?
What is the upstream branch?
o: The remote branch that a local branch tracks

q: What does @{u} or @{upstream} refer to?
o: The upstream branch of the current branch

q: How do you compare your branch with its upstream?
What does `git branch --unset-upstream` do?
What is the purpose of `git switch --detach`?
How do you switch to a remote branch for the first time?
What does `git branch -l` or `--list` do?
o: Lists branches matching an optional pattern

q: How do you filter branches by pattern?
What does `git branch --sort=refname` do?
What does `git branch --format` allow?
o: Custom output format for branch listing

q: How do you see the commit a branch points to?
What is the difference between merge and rebase for integrating branches?
o: Merge creates merge commit, rebase replays commits on top of target

q: When should you prefer merge over rebase?
o: When you want to preserve the complete history and branch structure

q: When should you prefer rebase over merge?
o: When you want a linear, cleaner history

q: What creates a merge conflict?
o: Same lines modified differently in branches being merged

q: How does Git indicate a merge conflict?
o: Conflict markers in affected files and message about unmerged paths

q: What are the three sections in a merge conflict marker?
o: HEAD version, separator (=======), other branch version

q: How do you resolve a merge conflict?
o: Edit file to desired state, remove markers, stage, and commit

q: What command shows files with conflicts during merge?
How do you complete the merge after resolving conflicts?
What does `git merge --continue` do?
o: Continues merge after conflicts are resolved

q: How do you abort an in-progress merge?
What does `git checkout --ours <file>` do during conflict?
o: Uses your branch's version of the file

q: What does `git checkout --theirs <file>` do during conflict?
o: Uses the other branch's version of the file

q: What is a fast-forward merge?
o: When target branch pointer simply moves forward with no merge commit

q: When can a fast-forward merge occur?
o: When there are no divergent commits on the target branch

q: What does `git merge --no-ff` ensure?
o: Creates a merge commit even if fast-forward is possible

q: Why would you want to disable fast-forward merges?
o: To preserve feature branch history and have clear merge points

q: What is a three-way merge?
o: Merge using common ancestor, ours, and theirs versions

q: What is the merge base?
o: The common ancestor commit of branches being merged

q: How do you find the merge base of two branches?
What does `git merge --squash` do?
o: Combines all branch changes into single commit without merge commit

q: After `git merge --squash`, what do you need to do?
What is the difference between merge --squash and regular merge?
o: Squash combines into one commit without branch history reference

q: What branching strategy uses long-lived feature branches?
What is trunk-based development?
o: Developers work on short-lived branches and merge frequently to main

q: What is GitHub Flow?
o: Simple workflow with main branch and feature branches

q: What is the difference between `git branch -d` and `git branch -D`?
o: -d is safe delete requiring merged, -D forces delete regardless

q: How does `git switch -c` differ from `git checkout -b`?
o: They do the same thing; switch is newer and branch-focused

q: What happens when you create a branch from another branch?
o: New branch starts at same commit as source branch

q: How do you push a new local branch to remote?
What does the -u flag in `git push -u origin branch` do?
o: Sets up tracking between local and remote branch

q: How do you view remote tracking branch information?
o: git branch -vv or git remote show origin

q: What does `git fetch origin <branch>` do?
o: Updates remote tracking branch without merging

q: How do you checkout a remote branch as a new local branch?
o: git checkout -b <local> origin/<remote> or git switch -c <local> origin/<remote>

q: What is the difference between fetch and pull regarding branches?
o: Fetch updates tracking branches, pull fetches and merges

q: What does `git branch --move` do?
How do you rename a remote branch?
o: Delete old remote branch, push renamed local branch

q: What is the purpose of branch protection rules?
o: Prevent force pushes and require reviews on important branches

q: Where are branch protection rules typically configured?
o: In the remote repository settings (GitHub, GitLab, etc.)

q: What is `git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD` used for?
How do you get just the branch name in a script?
o: git branch --show-current or git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD

q: What does `git branch --show-current` return?
o: The name of the current branch

q: How do you create a branch that doesn't inherit history?
What is an orphan branch useful for?
o: Creating completely separate history like gh-pages

q: What does `git log branch1..branch2` show?
o: Commits in branch2 that are not in branch1

q: What does `git log branch1...branch2` (three dots) show?
o: Commits in either branch but not both

q: How do you see commits ahead and behind between branches?
What does `git branch --edit-description` do?
o: Opens editor to add branch description

q: How do you view a branch's description?
What is the significance of short-lived feature branches?
o: Easier merges, less divergence, simpler code reviews

q: How often should feature branches be merged in trunk-based development?
o: Daily or within a few days

q: What is a stale branch?
o: A branch with no recent commits

q: How do you identify stale remote tracking branches?
What does `git fetch --prune` help with?
How do you configure automatic pruning on fetch?
What is the purpose of branch naming conventions?
o: Organize branches and indicate purpose at a glance

q: What is a common naming pattern for feature branches?
What is a common naming pattern for bugfix branches?
What does `git worktree` allow regarding branches?
o: Working on multiple branches simultaneously in different directories

q: What limitation exists for branches in worktrees?
o: Same branch cannot be checked out in multiple worktrees

q: What is merge resolution strategy selection?
o: Choosing how Git should handle combining changes

q: What does `git merge -s recursive -X ours` do?
o: Uses recursive strategy, preferring our changes in conflicts

q: What does `git merge -s recursive -X theirs` do?
o: Uses recursive strategy, preferring their changes in conflicts

q: What is the difference between -s ours and -X ours?
o: -s ours ignores theirs completely, -X ours resolves conflicts with ours

q: When would you use `git merge -s subtree`?
o: When merging a project into a subdirectory

q: What is a criss-cross merge scenario?
o: When branches have mutual merges creating complex ancestry

q: How does recursive merge strategy handle criss-cross?
o: Creates virtual merge base from common ancestors

q: What does `git merge --no-commit` do?
o: Performs merge but stops before committing

q: Why would you use `git merge --no-commit`?
o: To review or modify merge before committing

q: What does `git diff --merge-base branch` do?
o: Shows diff between merge base and branch

q: How do you preview merge conflicts before merging?
o: git merge --no-commit --no-ff then check, abort if needed

q: What does `git rerere enabled` setting do?
o: Automatically records and reuses conflict resolutions

q: How does rerere help with long-running branches?
o: Remembers how you resolved conflicts for repeated merges/rebases

q: What does `git rerere diff` show?
o: Current conflict state with recorded resolution

q: What is conflict staging in Git terms?
o: Files with conflicts have multiple stage entries (1, 2, 3)

q: What does stage 0 represent in the index?
What does stage 1 represent during conflict?
What does stage 2 represent during conflict?
What does stage 3 represent during conflict?
How do you view stage 2 version of a conflicted file?
What does `git diff --base` show during merge?
o: Changes from common ancestor to working directory

q: What does `git diff --ours` show during merge?
o: Changes from our version to working directory

q: What does `git diff --theirs` show during merge?
o: Changes from their version to working directory

q: What is the purpose of `git merge-file`?
o: Performs three-way merge on individual files

q: How does `git merge-tree` help?
o: Shows what merge would look like without modifying files

q: What is an octopus merge?
o: Merging more than two branches simultaneously

q: When is octopus merge useful?
o: Integrating multiple topic branches with no conflicts

q: What limitation does octopus merge have?
How do you perform an octopus merge?
What does `git merge --allow-unrelated-histories` permit?
o: Merging branches with no common ancestor

q: When would you need --allow-unrelated-histories?
What is the result of merging unrelated histories?
o: A merge commit combining both histories

q: How do you abort a merge after starting conflict resolution?
What happens to resolved files when you abort a merge?
o: All changes are reverted to pre-merge state

q: What is the difference between `git reset --hard HEAD` and `git merge --abort`?
o: --abort is merge-specific and safer; reset is more general

q: What does conflict marker `|||||||` indicate in diff3 style?
How do you enable diff3 conflict style globally?
Why is diff3 style helpful for resolving conflicts?
o: Shows what the original text was before changes

q: What does `git mergetool` launch?
o: A configured GUI or CLI tool for resolving conflicts

q: How do you configure a default merge tool?
What does `git mergetool --tool-help` show?
What .orig files does mergetool create?
o: Backup of conflicted file before resolution

q: How do you prevent mergetool from creating .orig files?
What happens when you resolve a conflict incorrectly?
o: Code may be broken; tests and review help catch this

q: How do you redo conflict resolution for a file?
o: git checkout -m <file> to restore conflict markers

q: What does the git merge MERGE_MSG file contain?
o: Default commit message for the merge

q: Where is MERGE_HEAD stored?
What does presence of MERGE_HEAD indicate?
How do you clean up after an incomplete merge?
o: git merge --abort or manually delete MERGE_HEAD and reset

q: What is merge commit's unique characteristic?
o: Has two or more parent commits

q: How do you identify a merge commit in git log?
What does `git log --merges` show?
What does `git log --no-merges` show?
How do you find when a branch was merged?
What is the purpose of preserving merge commits?
o: Maintains history of when features were integrated

q: What happens to merge commits during rebase?
o: They are typically linearized away unless using --preserve-merges

q: What does `git rebase --preserve-merges` do?
o: Attempts to keep merge commit structure during rebase

q: What replaced --preserve-merges in newer Git?
What does `git rebase --rebase-merges` do?
o: Recreates merge commits during rebase while maintaining topology

q: How do you squash commits when merging a branch?
What is the effect of squash merge on branch history?
o: Original branch commits are not referenced, only combined changes appear

q: When is squash merge preferred over regular merge?
o: When you want clean history without intermediate commits

q: What is the downside of squash merging?
o: Loses individual commit history and makes repeated merges harder

q: How do you configure default merge message format?
o: git config merge.log true or set merge.ff

q: What does `git merge --log` add?
o: One-line descriptions of commits to merge message

q: How do you set merge.log globally?
What is a merge tracking branch?
o: A branch that tracks what has been merged from another branch

q: How does `git branch --merged main` help?
o: Lists branches that have been fully merged into main

q: What does a merge bubble diagram show?
o: Visual representation of merge commits and branch topology

q: How do you visualize branch topology?
What does `git log --graph` display?
o: ASCII graph of commit history and branches

q: How do you compare two branches visually?
What is the purpose of `git show-branch`?
o: Shows branches with their commits and relationships

q: How do you see common ancestors between multiple branches?
What is a fork point in branching?
o: The commit where a branch originally diverged from its upstream

q: How does `git merge-base --fork-point` work?
o: Uses reflog to find the actual fork point

q: When is --fork-point useful?
o: When upstream has been rebased and you need correct base

q: What does `git merge-base --is-ancestor A B` check?
o: Whether A is an ancestor of B

q: How do you verify if a branch is fully merged?
o: git branch --merged | grep <branch> or git merge-base --is-ancestor

q: What is an evil merge?
o: A merge that introduces changes not in either parent

q: How can evil merges cause problems?
o: Changes are hidden and git bisect may miss them

q: How do you detect evil merges?
o: git log -p --cc to see combined diff of merges

q: What does -p --cc show for merge commits?
o: Combined diff showing changes not from either parent

q: What is a recursive merge conflict?
o: When merge base itself has conflicts requiring resolution

q: How does Git handle recursive merge base conflicts?
o: Creates virtual merge base with conflict markers

q: What are semantic conflicts?
o: Conflicts in meaning/behavior that Git cannot detect

q: How do you catch semantic conflicts?
o: Through tests and code review, not Git

q: What is merge queue in CI/CD context?
o: System that tests and merges branches sequentially

q: What problem does merge queue solve?
o: Prevents broken main from concurrent passing branches

q: What is branch by abstraction?
o: Gradually replacing old code while both coexist in main

q: When is branch by abstraction preferred over feature branches?
o: For large refactors that would cause long-lived branches

q: What are feature flags in relation to branching?
o: Runtime toggles that enable/disable features without branching

q: How do feature flags reduce branch overhead?
o: Allow incomplete features in main behind flags

q: What is release train in branching strategy?
o: Regular release schedule with cutoff for features

q: How does release train handle missed features?
o: They wait for the next scheduled release

q: What is environment branching?
o: Branches representing deployment environments like staging, prod

q: Why is environment branching sometimes considered an anti-pattern?
o: Creates divergence and merge complexity between environments

q: What is the GitHub Flow branching model?
o: Main branch + short-lived feature branches with PRs

q: How does GitHub Flow differ from GitFlow?
o: Simpler with no develop branch or release branches

q: What branches does GitFlow use?
What is the purpose of develop branch in GitFlow?
o: Integration branch for features before release

q: What is a release branch in GitFlow?
o: Branch for stabilizing before production release

q: What is a hotfix branch in GitFlow?
o: Branch for urgent production fixes from main

q: Where do hotfix branches get merged in GitFlow?
What is trunk-based development?
o: All developers commit to main/trunk with short-lived branches

q: What is the maximum recommended branch lifetime in trunk-based?
Why does trunk-based development prefer small commits?
o: Easier integration and less merge conflict risk

q: What enables trunk-based development to work safely?
o: Strong CI/CD, feature flags, and comprehensive tests

q: What is GitLab Flow?
o: Environment branches plus merge requests workflow

q: How does GitLab Flow handle environments?
o: Uses environment branches like staging, production

q: What is a protected branch?
o: Branch with restrictions on who can push or merge

q: What protections can be applied to branches?
o: Required reviews, status checks, no force push, linear history

q: What is required status check for branches?
o: CI jobs that must pass before merge is allowed

q: What is required reviewers for branches?
o: Specified people who must approve before merge

q: What does linear history requirement enforce?
o: Branches must be rebased before merge, no merge commits

q: What is CODEOWNERS file used for?
o: Auto-assigns reviewers based on file paths

q: How does CODEOWNERS integrate with branch protection?
o: Can require approval from code owners for relevant files

q: What is signed commits requirement?
o: Commits must be GPG signed, branches can require this

q: What is a deployment branch?
o: Branch that triggers automatic deployment when updated

q: How do deployment branches integrate with CI/CD?
o: Pushes trigger deployment pipelines to specific environments

q: What is branch naming automation?
o: Enforcing naming conventions through Git hooks or CI checks

q: What is a draft branch?
o: Work-in-progress branch not ready for review (GitHub Draft PR)

q: How do you mark a PR/MR as draft?
o: Use platform's draft feature or prefix title with WIP/Draft

q: What is a stacked branches workflow?
o: Series of dependent branches building on each other

q: What challenge does stacked branches create?
o: Updates to base branch require rebasing all dependent branches

q: What tools help manage stacked branches?
What is a monorepo branching challenge?
o: Single branch affects all projects, requiring careful coordination

q: How do feature flags help in monorepos?
o: Allow per-project feature enabling without branch coordination

q: What is sparse checkout useful for in branching?
o: Working on subset of files reduces branch size and conflicts

q: What is `git switch --orphan` used for?
o: Creating a branch with no history starting fresh

q: How does orphan branch differ from regular branch?
o: Has no parent commits, starts fresh history

q: What is the common use for orphan branches?
o: GitHub Pages, documentation, or unrelated project history

q: How do you create an orphan branch and clear the index?
o: git switch --orphan <name> then git rm -rf . if needed

q: What is a shallow branch?
o: Branch in a shallow clone with limited history depth

q: What limitations do shallow branches have?
o: Cannot access history beyond depth, some operations fail

q: How do you deepen a shallow branch?
What is branch garbage collection?
o: Cleaning up deleted branch refs and unreachable objects

q: How do you configure branch cleanup policies?
o: Set gc.reflogExpire and use git gc

q: What is a superproject in Git?
How do branch changes in submodules affect superproject?
o: Superproject must be updated to point to new submodule commits

q: What is `git branch --set-upstream-to` shorthand?
What happens when upstream is deleted but local branch exists?
o: Local branch becomes orphaned from tracking, shows gone in -vv

q: How do you find branches with gone upstreams?
What is recommended for cleaning up gone branches?
o: Review then delete with git branch -d, or script the cleanup

q: How do you list all branches sorted by author date?
What does `git for-each-ref` provide for branch management?
o: Flexible output formatting and filtering for all refs

q: How do you get branch info in a specific format?
What is `refs/heads/` in Git?
o: Namespace where local branches are stored

q: What is `refs/remotes/` in Git?
o: Namespace where remote tracking branches are stored

q: What is `refs/tags/` in Git?
How do you create a branch at a specific tag?
What happens when you checkout a tag directly?
o: Enters detached HEAD state at that tag

q: How do you push a branch with a different remote name?
What does `git push origin local:remote` syntax mean?
o: Push local branch to remote with name 'remote'

q: How do you force push after rebase without overwriting others' work?
What does --force-with-lease check before force pushing?
o: Remote ref matches expected value from last fetch

q: What can cause --force-with-lease to fail?
o: Someone pushed after your last fetch

q: How do you set --force-with-lease as default for push?
What is branch pinning?
o: Locking a branch to a specific commit in submodule

q: How does submodule branch differ from regular branch?
o: Submodule tracks specific commit, not branch tip by default

q: What does `git submodule update --remote` do?
o: Updates submodule to latest commit on its configured branch

q: How do you configure which branch a submodule tracks?
What is the HEAD file in .git directory?
o: Reference to current branch or commit

q: What is stored in .git/refs/heads/<branch>?
o: The commit hash the branch points to

q: How are packed refs different from loose refs?
o: Packed refs are in single file for efficiency, loose are individual files

q: What triggers ref packing?
What is reflog's role in branch recovery?
o: Records all ref changes, allowing recovery of deleted branches

q: How do you see reflog for a specific branch?
What does branch@{n} notation reference?
o: The nth previous position of that branch

q: How do you recover a branch deleted 5 operations ago?
o: Find in reflog, create branch: git branch <name> HEAD@{5}

q: What is git worktree's relationship with branches?
o: Each worktree has a branch checked out, cannot duplicate

q: How do you see which branch each worktree has checked out?
What error occurs when switching to branch already in worktree?
How do you work around worktree branch limitation?
o: Create a new branch from the locked one in the new worktree

q: What is `git update-ref` used for?
o: Low-level command to update reference values safely

q: How does `git update-ref` handle atomic updates?
o: Checks old value before updating, preventing race conditions

q: What is the purpose of `git symbolic-ref`?
How do you check what HEAD points to?
What does `git name-rev` do?
o: Names revisions using symbolic names from refs

q: How does `git describe` help identify commits?
o: Gives human-readable name based on nearest tag

q: What does `git describe --all` include?
o: Uses any ref not just tags for naming

q: What is namespace in Git refs?
o: Organizational hierarchy for refs like refs/heads, refs/remotes

q: What is `refs/stash` used for?
o: Stores the most recent stash entry

q: What is `refs/bisect/` used for?
o: Temporary refs during git bisect operation

q: What is `refs/notes/` used for?
o: Stores git notes attached to commits

q: How do fetch refspecs control branch fetching?
o: Defines which refs to fetch and where to store them

q: What is the default fetch refspec format?
What does the + in refspec mean?
o: Force update even if not fast-forward

q: How do you configure a custom fetch refspec?
What is push refspec?
o: Configuration determining what refs to push and where

q: How do you configure default push behavior?
What push.default modes exist?
What does push.default 'simple' do?
o: Pushes current branch to upstream if names match

q: What does push.default 'current' do?
o: Pushes current branch to same-named remote branch

q: What is mirror push?
o: Pushes all refs making remote mirror of local

q: How do you set up a mirror remote?
What is the difference between fetch and pull mirror?
o: Fetch mirror receives, push mirror sends - mirroring direction

q: What does `git ls-remote` show?
o: References available at a remote repository

q: How do you check remote branch without fetching?
What is `git remote update`?
How does `git remote update` differ from `git fetch --all`?
o: Functionally similar, update respects remote.*.skipFetchAll config

q: What is remote.origin.skipFetchAll?
o: Excludes remote from git fetch --all and remote update

q: How do you add a second remote to a repo?
What is the triangle workflow in Git?
o: Fetching from upstream, pushing to fork, PR to upstream

q: How do you configure triangle workflow?
o: Set upstream to fetch from and origin to push to

q: What does `remote.pushDefault` configure?
o: Default remote to push to when not specified

q: What is `branch.<name>.pushRemote` for?
How do you track a branch from non-origin remote?
What is `git branch --track` default behavior?
o: Sets up tracking when branching from remote-tracking branch

q: How do you configure branch autosetupRemote?
What does push.autoSetupRemote do?
o: Automatically sets upstream when pushing new branch

q: What is branch.<name>.rebase configuration?
o: Per-branch setting to rebase instead of merge on pull

q: How do you always rebase when pulling a specific branch?
What does `git config pull.rebase interactive` do?
o: Runs interactive rebase instead of merge on pull

q: What is `git branch --column` used for?
o: Displays branches in columns for better readability

q: How do you configure default column display?
What does `git branch --color` control?
How do you customize branch colors?
What branch color slots exist?
What does `git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name` show?
o: Full symbolic reference name like refs/heads/main

q: How do you get the remote tracking branch for current branch?
What is `git log --oneline --decorate` useful for?
o: Shows commits with branch and tag labels

q: How does `--decorate=full` differ from default?
o: Shows full ref names including refs/heads/

q: What does `git log --source` add to output?
o: Shows which ref each commit was reached from

q: How do you find which branch a commit came from?
What does `git log --first-parent` show?
o: Only first parent of merge commits, showing branch mainline

q: Why use --first-parent for main branch history?
o: Shows clean mainline without feature branch commits

q: What is `git log --ancestry-path A..B`?
o: Commits that are ancestors of B AND descendants of A

q: When is --ancestry-path useful for branch analysis?
o: Finding commits on a specific path between branches

q: What does `git rev-list --count branch1..branch2` return?
o: Number of commits in branch2 not in branch1

q: How do you count commits ahead and behind?
What format does left-right count output use?
o: Two numbers: left-only and right-only commits

q: What is `git branch --format='%(upstream:track)'`?
o: Shows ahead/behind status relative to upstream

q: What does %(upstream:trackshort) format show?
What is the purpose of git branch --format='%(if)%(upstream)%(then)...'?
o: Conditional formatting based on whether branch has upstream

q: How do you script bulk branch operations?
o: Use git for-each-ref with --shell or pipe to xargs

q: What does `git for-each-ref --shell` provide?
o: Output suitable for shell eval with proper quoting

q: How do you delete all merged branches except main?
o: git branch --merged | grep -v main | xargs git branch -d

q: What safety does the above approach have?
o: -d requires merge, so unmerged work is protected

q: What is branch locking in Git hosting?
o: Preventing all changes to a branch temporarily

q: How does branch locking differ from protection?
o: Locking is total block, protection allows approved changes

q: What is auto-delete branch feature?
o: Automatically deletes branch after PR merge

q: How do you configure auto-delete on GitHub?
o: Repository settings: Automatically delete head branches

q: What is the purpose of default branch configuration?
o: Sets which branch shown by default and is PR target

q: How do you change the default branch?
o: In repository settings on hosting platform

q: What happens when you change default branch?
o: PRs retarget, clone default changes, protection may need update

q: What is branch alias in Git?
o: Symbolic ref pointing to another branch

q: How do you create a branch alias?
What is the limitation of branch aliases?
o: Shows as separate branch, not widely supported

q: What is heads-up when dealing with case-sensitive branch names?
o: Windows/macOS may have issues with Main vs main

q: How do you handle cross-platform branch name case issues?
o: Standardize on lowercase, configure core.ignoreCase carefully

q: What does git config core.ignoreCase affect?
o: How Git handles file and ref name case sensitivity

q: What is the maximum branch name length in Git?
o: No hard limit from Git, but filesystem limits apply (~255 chars)

q: What characters are prohibited in branch names?
What does `git check-ref-format --branch` validate?
o: Whether a string is a valid branch name

q: How do you rename a branch safely across team?
o: Communicate, rename local, push new, delete old remote, update tracking

q: What steps update local after remote branch rename?
o: git fetch --prune, checkout new name, delete old local if needed

q: What is the impact of renaming a branch with open PRs?
o: PRs may need manual retargeting or recreation

q: What is branch archiving?
o: Moving old branches to a different namespace like refs/archive/

q: How do you archive a branch to refs/archive/?
o: git update-ref refs/archive/<name> refs/heads/<name>; delete branch

q: What benefit does branch archiving provide?
o: Keeps refs without cluttering branch list

q: What are Git notes used for in branch context?
o: Adding metadata to commits without changing them

q: How do notes survive rebasing?
o: They don't by default; notes.rewriteRef config helps

q: What is notes.rewriteRef configuration?
o: Tells Git to copy notes when commits are rewritten

q: What is the relationship between branches and CI pipelines?
o: Different branches can trigger different pipeline configurations

q: How do branch rules affect CI in GitHub Actions?
o: Workflow can define branch triggers with on.push.branches

q: What is branch-based environment promotion?
o: Moving code between branches that represent environments

q: What are the risks of environment branches?
What alternative to environment branches is often preferred?
o: Single branch with continuous deployment and feature flags

q: What is branch-specific .gitignore?
o: Different ignore rules per branch using sparse-checkout or hooks

q: How do you maintain different files per branch?
o: Track in both but use hooks or sparse-checkout for working dir

q: What is the recommended approach for long-running branches?
o: Regular merges from main to stay synchronized

q: What problem does branch divergence cause?
o: Harder merges, more conflicts, integration delays

q: How do you measure branch health?
o: Check behind count, age, test status, review status

q: What tools help visualize branch complexity?
o: Git log --graph, gitk, IDE visualizers, GitHub Insights

q: What is branch codeowner concept?
o: Assigning responsibility for branches similar to file CODEOWNERS

q: How do branch access controls work?
o: Platform rules restrict who can push/merge to protected branches

q: What is force push disabled protection?
o: Prevents history rewriting on protected branches

q: What happens when force push is attempted on protected branch?
o: Push is rejected with error message

q: What is the include-administrators option?
o: Applies protection rules even to repository admins

q: Why might you exclude administrators from protection?
o: Allow emergency fixes or rule exceptions

q: What is allow-force-pushes protection option?
o: Permits force push for specific users on protected branch

q: What is allow-deletions protection option?
o: Permits branch deletion for authorized users

q: How do deployment environments relate to branches?
o: Environments can have branch restrictions for deployment

q: What is environment protection in GitHub?
o: Rules requiring reviews or waiting before deploying to environment

q: How do deployment branches differ from environment branches?
o: Deployment branches trigger deploys; environment branches ARE environments

q: What is branch ruleset in newer GitHub features?
o: Flexible rules that can apply to multiple branch patterns

q: How do rulesets differ from branch protection rules?
o: Rulesets are more flexible, can be org-wide, and overlap

q: What repository setting affects branch visibility?
Can you have private branches in a public repo?
o: No, all branches are visible in public repositories

q: What is the impact of branch strategy on CI costs?
o: More branches = more CI runs, affecting compute costs

q: How do you optimize CI for multiple branches?
o: Path-based triggers, caching, conditional jobs, draft detection

q: What is the skip ci convention?
o: Commit message containing [skip ci] to avoid triggering pipelines

q: When is skip ci appropriate?
o: Documentation-only changes, readme updates, trivial fixes

q: What is merge training in merge queues?
o: Testing PR merged with latest main before actual merge

q: How does merge queue prevent broken main?
o: Tests rebased version of PR against latest main before merge

q: What is speculative merging in merge queues?
o: Testing multiple PRs merged together for faster throughput

q: What configuration reduces merge queue latency?
o: Batch size, parallel builds, fast-failing tests

q: What are best practices for branch naming in teams?
o: Consistent prefixes, ticket refs, lowercase, descriptive names

q: What should be documented about branching strategy?
o: Branch types, naming conventions, merge policies, protection rules

q: What is the role of CONTRIBUTING.md in branching?
o: Documents how contributors should create and manage branches

q: How do you enforce branching conventions?
o: Pre-push hooks, CI checks, or branch protection patterns

q: What is branch pattern matching in protection rules?
o: Wildcards like release/* to protect multiple branches

q: What patterns are supported in branch protection?
How do you protect all release branches?
What happens when multiple protection rules match?
o: Most specific match or combination applies (platform-specific)

q: What is require conversation resolution setting?
o: PR comments must be resolved before merge

q: What is require deployments to succeed setting?
o: Deployment to environment must succeed before merge

q: How do branch restrictions aid compliance?
o: Audit trail of who merged what, required approvals, signed commits

q: What audit capabilities exist for branch changes?
o: Audit logs show push, delete, protection changes

q: How do you restore a branch from audit log?
o: Find commit hash in log, create branch from it

q: What is branch cache in CI systems?
o: Caching build artifacts per branch to speed up builds

q: How do branch caches affect storage costs?
o: More branches = more cache storage needed

q: What is the purpose of branch creation events?
o: Trigger automations like initial CI setup or notifications

q: How do webhooks relate to branch operations?
o: Webhooks can trigger on push, create, delete branch events

q: What automation can branch deletion webhook trigger?
o: Cleanup resources, remove deployments, notify team

q: What is the best practice for main branch state?
o: Always deployable, all tests passing, properly reviewed

q: What does 'shift left' mean for branch quality?
o: Catch issues earlier in feature branches before merge

q: How do feature flags enable trunk-based without risk?
o: Incomplete features are hidden in production behind flags

q: What metrics indicate healthy branch management?
o: PR size, time to merge, branch lifespan, conflict frequency

q: What is branch debt?
o: Accumulation of old, stale, or diverged branches needing cleanup

q: How do you reduce branch debt?
o: Regular cleanup, shorter lifespans, automated deletion after merge

q: What is the relationship between commits and branches?
o: Branches are movable pointers to commits, commits form the DAG

q: Why are branches called 'cheap' in Git?
o: Just 41-byte files pointing to commits, no file copying

q: What is contained in .git/refs/heads/ directory?
o: One file per local branch containing commit hash

q: What happens to refs when git gc runs?
o: Loose refs may be packed into packed-refs file

q: What is the packed-refs file?
o: Single file containing many refs for efficiency

q: How do you manually pack refs?
What advantage does packed-refs provide?
What is `git show-ref` used for?
How does `git show-ref --heads` differ from `--tags`?
What is `git show-ref --verify` for?
What does `git for-each-ref --contains <commit>` show?
o: Refs that contain the specified commit

q: How do you find all refs pointing to a specific commit?
What is branch.<name>.description used for?
o: Stores optional description text for the branch

q: How do you read a branch description?
What tools use branch descriptions?
o: git format-patch for cover letter, some GUIs

q: What is the difference between HEAD and head?
o: HEAD is the special ref; head is part of refs/heads/

q: What does ORIG_HEAD store?
o: Previous HEAD position before dangerous operations

q: When is ORIG_HEAD set?
o: After merge, rebase, reset that moves HEAD significantly

q: How do you use ORIG_HEAD to undo a merge?
What is FETCH_HEAD?
o: Records what was fetched from remote

q: What does MERGE_HEAD contain?
o: Commit being merged into current branch

q: What indicates CHERRY_PICK_HEAD?
o: Commit being cherry-picked during conflict resolution

q: What is REBASE_HEAD?
o: Commit being replayed during rebase conflict

q: What does branch.<name>.merge configure?
o: Remote ref to merge for git pull

q: What does branch.<name>.remote specify?
o: Which remote to fetch/push for this branch

q: How do upstream settings affect git push?
o: Push goes to configured upstream by default

q: What is the difference between origin/main and origin main?
o: origin/main is tracking branch, origin main is remote + branch

q: What creates a remote tracking branch?
Can you commit directly to a remote tracking branch?
o: No, they are read-only references to remote state

q: What happens when you checkout a remote tracking branch?
o: Enters detached HEAD or creates local branch (with auto-setup)

q: What is branch.autoSetupMerge configuration?
o: Controls automatic upstream setup when checking out remote branch

q: What values can branch.autoSetupMerge have?
What is branch.autoSetupRebase configuration?
o: Controls whether new branches rebase by default on pull

q: How do you configure a branch to always rebase on pull?
What is the format of .git/config branch section?
How do you remove upstream from a branch?
What effect does --unset-upstream have on push?
o: Push requires explicit remote and branch specification

q: How do you see all branches with their upstream?
What does -vv show that -v doesn't?
o: Upstream branch name and ahead/behind counts

q: What is the purpose of @{push}?
o: Refers to where branch would push to (may differ from upstream)

q: When does @{push} differ from @{upstream}?
o: In triangle workflows with separate fetch and push remotes

q: How do you compare with push target?
What is the purpose of git rev-parse @{-1}?
o: Gets the previous branch that was checked out

q: What does @{-n} notation reference?
o: The nth previously checked out branch

q: How do you switch to the last branch quickly?
What is branch reflog expiration?
o: How long branch reflog entries are kept

q: What is gc.reflogExpireUnreachable default?
What is gc.reflogExpire default?
How do you prevent branch reflog from expiring?
o: Set gc.reflogExpire and gc.reflogExpireUnreachable to never

q: What is branch-level reflog vs HEAD reflog?
o: refs/heads/<branch> tracks branch tip; HEAD tracks current position

q: Which reflog survives branch deletion?
o: HEAD reflog retains info, branch reflog is deleted
